resources.string: 1. Click one of the dropdown arrows for the category where you think the problem lies. For example, if your monitor is experiencing some issue, a good option to try is the Monitors category. Click on the arrow next to Monitors.
As shown in the picture below, your device name should now show up.
2. Right click on the device name and a little menu is displayed. Click on “Update Driver Software…”
3. A new window opens up as shown in the picture below. Click the first option that says “Search automatically for updated driver software”.

4. Windows will now search online for any updated device drivers the selected device may need. The search should complete in about a minute, more or less.\n\n If an updated driver is found for the specified device, it will automatically begin downloading and installing which could take anywhere from a few seconds to five minutes.
5. After installation is complete, the window below will now show (with your device’s name specified instead).

6. Restart your computer and test out the malfunctioning device. 90% of the time, this will fix the issue. If your problem is resolved, congratulations you no longer have to read this guide. But if no driver was found or if your problem persists even after a driver was installed using this method, there is still one more thing you can try.
1. Go to the manufacturer’s website. For example, if your computer is made by HP, go to www.hp.com.

2. Once you’re at the manufacturer’s website, look for a button or link that says “Support”. Every website is different so you may need to scan the page for the Support link. It is usually found in the menu or at the bottom of the page. Below is an example of the Support button on HP’s website.

3. Once you find it, click it, and the loaded page should have a link saying something similar to “Device Drivers and Downloads”.

On HP’s website specifically, when the Support button is hovered with the mouse cursor, a drop down menu appears. One of the options displayed is “Software & drivers”. Click that option. Each website is different so be on the lookout for different phrases. Almost all of them should include the word “drivers” in them.

If you can’t find that link or the Support link, you can try a Google search with the following search string: “[manufacturer’s name] device drivers”. The correct link should be the first or second result.

4. Next you will have to identify your computer. The page may ask for your computer’s product name, product ID, serial key, service tag, or something else of that sort. The below image shows HP’s page.

If you find that information on your computer, which is usually a little sticker on the back or front of your tower if you’re using a desktop or somewhere on the back if you’re using a laptop, enter that information.\n\nSubmit the ID or key and it will immediately find your exact computer model. If you don’t have or can’t find that information, there should be an option where you can enter your computer’s model name. The model name should be engraved somewhere on your computer. If your computer is made by HP, a model name would be Pavilion x360, for example. The picture below gives an example where that information can be found.
5. The resulting page should show a list of categories similar to the image below.
Find the category you think may be the issue and download the most recent file. HOWEVER, make sure the file you download is actually a driver. The picture below shows what to be looking for.

Notice the word “Driver” in some of categories. The one you select must be one containing the word “Driver”. If there are multiple drivers available in the category you select, go with the most updated one. Once it’s downloaded, run the file and an install wizard should show up. Follow the install process, restart your computer, and see if that fixed the problem.

6. If the problem remains, try installing a different driver on the same support page. If all else fails, try Googling your problem and see if anything useful shows up. After you tried those methods and the problem still hasn’t fixed, you may safely conclude it’s the device that is the problem, not the device drivers. In this unfortunate case, you may need to take the device to a repair shop or have it replaced.
